column1: #This mapping was created following and expanding upon the SSSOM guidance: https://mapping-commons.github.io/sssom/spec/

column16: comment

'original spatial coordinates of the location' is semantically broader than 'latitude and longitude'. Note that the Coordinate Reference System 'epsg:4326' must be provided explicitly in dwc:verbatimSRS in order for the mapping to be complete.
DwC expects only the latitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
DwC expects only the longitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
DwC expects only the latitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
DwC expects only the longitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)

Both terms focus on a depth/vertical distance *below* some surface. Note that in Darwin Core, according to best practices, depth is measured in water from an air-water surface, while in other media the corresponding terms are dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters, where the values would be negative for depth. Thus, for a sediment at the bottom of a lake, there would be an elevation of the lake surface, the depth of the top of the sediment in the lake, and minimum and maximum distances below the sediment surface within which a sample was taken.

column2: Minimum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:depth as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:depth definition only allows for depth ("below" the surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:depth field allowing ranges or single points, while DwC expects only the upper depth/lower altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in Darwin Core, according to best practices, depth is measured in water from an air-water surface, while in other media the corresponding terms are dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters, where the values would be negative for depth. Thus, for a sediment at the bottom of a lake, there would be an elevation of the lake surface, the depth of the top of the sediment in the lake, and minimum and maximum distances below the sediment surface within which a sample was taken.

column2: Maximum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:depth as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:depth definition only allows for depth ("below" the surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:depth field allowing ranges or single points, while DwC expects only the lower depth/upper altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in Darwin Core, according to best practices, depth is measured in water from an air-water surface, while in other media the corresponding terms are dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters, where the values would be negative for depth. Thus, for a sediment at the bottom of a lake, there would be an elevation of the lake surface, the depth of the top of the sediment in the lake, and minimum and maximum distances below the sediment surface within which a sample was taken.

The DwC term specifically addresses a range of depths, for which this term gives the minimum depth, whereas the MIxS term does not specify that it is about a depth range (expecting either a single depth measurement or a range)

The DwC term specifically addresses a range of depths, for which this term gives the maximum depth, whereas the MIxS term does not specify that it is about a depth range (expecting either a single depth measurement or a range)

column2: Minimum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:alt as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:alt definition only allows for altitude ("above" the earth's surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:alt field allowing ranges or single points (clarified in https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/389), while DwC expects only the upper depth/lower altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in DwC, a range of altitude can be captured in the combination of the terms dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAbveSurfaceInMeters. If a single value is given, the same value should be used in both DwC terms.

column2: Maximum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:alt as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:alt definition only allows for altitude ("above" the earth's surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:alt field allowing ranges or single points (clarified in https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/389), while DwC expects only the upper depth/lower altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in DwC, a range of altitude can be captured in the combination of the terms dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAbveSurfaceInMeters. If a single value is given, the same value should be used in both DwC terms.

Note that the MIxS term definition loosely distinguishes between elevation and altitude (Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit.), while the DwC term definition essentially equates them.
DwC expects only the lower elevation limit in meter (narrower), while MIxS expects a single point or range of elevation measurement(s) at which the sample was taken.
DwC expects only the upper elevation limit in meter (narrower), while MIxS expects a single point or range of elevation measurement(s) at which the sample was taken.
the MIxS term includes both seas and countries, while DwC only refers to the country
the MIxS term includes both seas and countries, while DwC only refers to the sea.
DwC term encompasses any combination of geographic region names, while the MIxS term may either be the name of a country or a sea, followed by additional region information
Events are semantically broader than sampling events (e.g. they could include observations too)

The range of the MIxS examples is [free living|parasitism|commensalism|symbiotic|mutualism]. While the expectation created by the MIxS definition [parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y] would exactly match the DwC term, the examples given by MIxS do not. We’ve opened an issue requesting this mismatch to be fixed on the GSC/MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/168. Focusing on the MIxS value syntax, it seems that the MIxS term is broader than the DwC term, as the latter will be more precise in any arbitrary case. E.g. Some worm is a parasite of a clam: DwC would capture parasite of clam, while MIxS would capture parasite of. One could also capture relationships with more metadata about the assertion using the ResourceRelationship extension to Darwin Core.

dwc:samplingProtocol covers both of the concepts samp_collect_device and samp_collect_process. , however,   the MIxS samp_collect_device field can accept either a reference to a protocol or a device, making it broader than the DwC field that only accepts protocol references. Based on the examples these could also be skos:exactMatch, but we are focusing on the definition for the semantic mapping. Please also note that the information that the dwc term and the samp_mat_process capture is often captured in the method steps in the EML (metadata about the dataset, not indexed in GBIF’s case), and less in the DwC terms themselves. This influences how people will use the terms in reality.

dwc:samplingProtocol covers both of the concepts samp_collect_device and samp_collect_process. The object is narrower as the scope of the references in the MIxS field is limited; “The name of, reference to, or description of the method [...]” vs a specific ontology term. The information that this term and samp_collect_device capture is often captured in the method steps in the EML (metadata about the dataset, not indexed in GBIF’s case), and less in the DwC terms themselves. This influences how people will use the terms in reality.
dwc:sampleSizeValue requires the units of the measure to be given in dwc:sampleSizeUnit.
dwc:sampleSizeUnit  must accompany the measure given in dwc:sampleSizeValue.

This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.

This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67. DwC expects only the identifiers (DOI to publication, global unique ID, URI) to associated taxa, while MIxS seems to expect a url to anything related

Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
